paper_title.en: Localization of electromagnetic waves in three-dimensional fractal cavities

description.en: Three-dimensional fractals called the Menger sponge, with a fractal dimension D=log20/log3, were fabricated from epoxy resin by stereolithography. Clear attenuation of both reflection and transmission intensity was observed at 12.8 GHz for a cubic specimen with an edge size of 27 mm that was constructed up to the third stage of the self-similar patterns. The electromagnetic field was found to be confined in the central part of the specimen at this frequency. The localization is not caused by the presence of a photonic band gap as in photonic crystals but should be attributed to a singular photon density of states realized in the fractal structure. This is the first report on such localization of electromagnetic waves in three-dimensional fractal cavities.

paper_title.en: Smart Processing Development of Photonic Crystals and Fractals
New synthesis route for Si2N2O ceramics based on desert sand

description.en: A new approach for synthesis and sintering of silicon oxynitride starting from a unique natural raw material, desert sand is described. The sand in a mixture with silicon metal is combusted under pressurized nitrogen gas into pure silicon oxynitride powder. Then, this powder is densified in the presence of 5 wt % calcia-alumina mixture to a compact with about 99% of theoretical density within 6 min heating up and holding by using the spark plasma sintering technique. The dense silicon oxynitride has 18.7 GPa Vickers hardness, 3.3 MPa m(1/2) fracture toughness, and 363 MPa strength. Morphology of a fractured surface shows that the grains are equiaxed and the fracture occurs in transgranular mode. The material exhibited excellent oxidation resistance at high temperatures up to 1500 degreesC as well as outstanding chemical resistance in acidic, alkaline and salt mediums at room temperature. (C) 2003 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: JOURNAL OF THE EUROPEAN CERAMIC SOCIETY

paper_title.en: Direct slicing from AutoCAD solid models for rapid prototyping

description.en: To meet the requirement of faster and precise slicing in rapid prototyping, a direct slicing approach from AutoCAD solid models is proposed. The sliced layers are saved in ASCII DXF files. Lines, arcs and circles are used to describe the section contours. This approach can be used in stereolithography, selective laser sintering, fused deposition modelling, and other rapid prototyping processes, e.g. laminated object manufactuing.

publication_name.en: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF ADVANCED MANUFACTURING TECHNOLOGY

paper_title.en: Ecomaterials synthesis and recycling by nitriding combustion

description.en: Nitriding combustion can be applied to waste recycling to produce usable ceramics as well as high performance ceramics at low cost. Some successful conversions of reclaimed silicon to silicon nitride, silicon sludge and aluminum dross to sialon-based ceramics, and desert sand to silicon oxynitride are demonstrated. (C) 2003 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: CURRENT OPINION IN SOLID STATE & MATERIALS SCIENCE

paper_title.ja: Process Control of Reactive Rapid Prototyping for Nickel-alminides-Ⅱ
paper_title.en: Process control of reactive rapid prototyping for nickel-aluminides-II

description.en: Reactive rapid prototyping is a new freeform fabrication method for intermetallics which is a combined process of the combustion synthesis and rapid prototyping. Nickel-aluminide objects are built through microjoining of small nickel-alummide beads which are formed by ejecting fused aluminum droplets onto a nickel powder bed. In order to obtain fine objects, it is necessary to minimize the bead size and control the product's composition. Nickel addition to aluminum was effective to reduce the reaction heat for a decrease in a bead size. Increasing temperature of aluminum droplets to 1000 degreesC tended to form beads being rich in NiAl phase. A newly developed nozzle with double orifices could eject aluminum droplets uniformly and continuously, resulting in forming a thin line of nickel-aluminide with similar to 0.7 mm in width and a simple 2D structure with a few pores and cracks. (C) 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: MATERIALS SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING A-STRUCTURAL MATERIALS PROPERTIES MICROSTRUCTURE AND PROCESSING
